description: Works flawlessly. I just have 2 complaints: 1) There is no option to import your chat history for a new device. 2) The app has to update way too often (several times a week) in order to work. I don't appreciate that.
Fine on KDE but GNOME gives you weird graphical glitches when trying to use it. The app in itself is heavenly.
Has absolutely no issues and works just as it does on every other OS/platform I've tried Signal on. Hurrah!
Secure and open source messenger with a bunch of helpful features, what more do you need to say?
I was surprised how well this works with FC 37 via flatpack. Likely the best quality video call I've ever fielded.
Signal is very nice

I've been using Signal from the time that it was still named TextSecure on Android. It is a very secure and privacy respecting messenger application for chatting with phones, but also the desktop. Highly recommended.
Signal is a great state of art private chat service. Using it since two years!
Signal is amazing !

it's not a native GNOME app, so it'll look weird, behave weird, and be really slow, sucking up your RAM. It also needs to be linked with your phone, somewhat like WhatsApp. Personally, Ring, and Matrix (Fractal) are better.
Best messaging app for privacy
Its rather slow starting and is not a native app GTK/Qt app. Other than that it works great!
I stopped using Signal over 6 months ago since they don't provide official installations for non-Debian-based systems. They should maintain this Flatpak, not the community.

No excuse for lack of resources.

1 window + 1 settings dialog + 1 message frame. They are all available in Qt. 1 single average Chinese developer can code this app in Qt in 1 single month.

By picking Electron in the first place, you dug yourself a very big-big-big hole.

I generally like Signal on other platforms, but the desktop app is a bit disappointing. It works… eventually. It takes FOREVER to launch, and seemingly exponentially longer the more messages and contacts you have (it doesn't appear to cache anything). It's pretty clearly some sort of web or Electron app, which normally would be okay but it just feels super non-native. It also uses non-native Apple-styled emoji instead of the system emoji, so it doesn't fit in with other apps.

Signal installed for me under ubuntu-mate through a flatpak. But no link appeared in the start menu, nor was in findable through a search. The only way I could run it was through visiting the installation page on flatpak, which opened a launch window for me. Hope this gets fixed.
summary: Agree, it works, but needs more love and attention

description: Signal is great and nothing compares to it in terms of privacy. The only issues I have with this client is the lack of VoIP support and it's built on electron, so it tends to be bloated.

Very little improvement over the years, severely lacking in features, painfully slow to load in some scenarios, etc. I really don't mean to be rude—I'm really thankful for the work Open Whisper has done and depend on it to communicate with a little but hopeful privacy—but, ever since its inception as a Chrome App, it feels like this application has been just a way to keep people relatively quiet about desktop support. Meaning that they see no value in it or aren't interested in it, but don't want to deal with the problem that their users *do* want a real, private chat experience on the Desktop.
summary: Signal is awesome, this app is not

description: the last updates turned signal very anoying like I almost everytime have to provide some pins to start the app, futhermore also i will be directed to change those pins, so now i am uninstalling it, do not have time for such games

The good:

 - secure messaging
 - secure and encrypted calls (audio/video)
 - synced with your phone
 - goodies like stickers, images, message reactions

The bad:

 - is basically a browser instance of Chromium (aka Electron)
 * more RAM usage
 * more storage usage
 - slow startup
 - once in a while slow UI
 - video calls are still a little buggy (frame freezes and skipping)
THE GREATEST APP ON THE PLANET
summary: THE GREATEST APP ON THE PLANET

description: What I mean is this flatpak packaged by Signal themselves or a 3rd party? A rather important question, otherwise one should maybe download it from the official website.
Much better than whatsapp desktop. Once linked it works even with phone switched off. Messages and calls are fast and secure.
there should be a sync between devices, but there is none
Compared to Telegram messenger Signal's editing capabilities are very limited.

As many have said, it's not official & could have risk of being dangerous but it's not entirely true. It's maintained by a bunch of Open Source contributors. And the Flathub members & a 24/7 running bot watches this & all other packages flathub packages. Thus there's a very little chance of it/other packages being vulnerable
But this package can be outdated. As Open Source contributors are volunteers who contributes in their own free time. Thus this package can have some delays to get updated to the latest official version
Keeps crashing and refuses to work without hanging every 5 minutes.
I haven't come across any issues so far. Nice and easy to use and easy to set up
summary: Really nice messaging application. The flatpak seems flawless as well

description: I found it updated more often than snap. It also seems to work faster
This is not an official package from Signal.org and should be marked as such. Signal does not yet provide an official version for Fedora / RPM-based distros.
summary: Not clear that it's unofficial package

description: The whole system freezes on launch. You shouldn't use it for now.
This is not an official build of Signal Desktop. It works fine, but don't use it unless you trust all the contributors listed on https://github.com/flathub/org.signal.Signal/graphs/contributors.

Why is this messaging app 300MB ?? Strange that sending messages should take such a large application... does not make sense.
Otherwise - great app, which hopefully keeps NSA away.
Love it as an alternative to other messengers

The desktop client is okay I guess. It does the job and lets me send Signal messages to my contacts, but other than that it's not that great and doesnt feel as polished as the mobile apps.

I also think its dumb that adding stickers to your account is only available on the desktop client. That should probably be a mobile feature too since thats where most people use Signal.
summary: It works, but could be better

description:
Signal is a great app and a needed service. 

This flatpak version provides this service to the all linux distros. 
Thank you to the people that worked on this.
summary: great app, and a must have for those that care about security

description: Good, fast and realiable secure messaging app. It would be great if minimizing to tray is also supported,
Great to read it's secure, well it's also reliable, with the features needed
Love that I can connect my desktop application with signal on android so easy.
I use Signal on my phone, but I prefer using this desktop app, because I can use a keyboard. I would like Signal desktop to be able to function without Signal on a phone.
summary: Excellent to use next to Signal on the phone

description: It is nice, but electron.js makes it way too large; a deal breaker for me.

Great for security. Still some maturing to be done. Like you can't change or add to the spell-check language of the auto-correct. It can only use the overall system language. Which for bilinguals like me is a bummer.
Just a blank screen under wayland. Huge reason to use flatpak is the added security under wayland. No point to this package
summary: Does not work at all in Wayland

description:
Apps performance is very poor. 
It's slow & size is huge.
App is not polished.
I found Signal on Linux brilliant via flatpak works and have never failed me yet been using it for a few years now dont understand why there are negative reviews as its been top notch for me.
summary: works perfect been using it for years and it just gets better

description: good stuff, love it, works great
With the additional argument --use-tray-icon its perfect. Thanks!!
Does what is says on the tin.
Can fix the answer a message with sticker?

Definitely one of the, if not the best messenger right now.
Just give it a try, you will love it.

On Ubuntu it works 5 seconds and then shuts down.
None of the suggestions researched in tutorials and blogs solved this problem.
Signal is a great app. It needs better managing of stickers though.
Good UI fast and reliable

The App is not very responsive but looks acceptable with the current defualt gnome theme. 
The App won't sync your chat hisoties for the time before you installed it.
Great app, easy to use, easy to share. Share and use and share some more.
summary: Move your friends and family to Signal!

description: Import der Kontakte Funktioniert nicht.
Schöne Anwendung, nativer Client für Linux und seit dem Update auf V1.16.2 startet sie auch schnell. Das einzige, dass fehlt ist die Möglichkeit sein eigenes Profil auf dem Computer zu bearbeiten.
Sicherer und einfacher messenger, der die Funktionen mit sich bringt, die man braucht, Synchronisation habe ich getestet, funktioniert mit Feodora perfekt
Auf Fedora funktionierts hervoragend. Alle Gifs und Sticker sind da.
... funktioniert, nur werden diese nicht angezeigt. Wenn ich nach einem Kontakt suche, dann wird er angezeigt. Is it a feature or a bug?!
Videokonferenzen auch mit mehreren Teilnehmern und Bildschirmfreigabe in toller Qualität

Hervorragend. Einmal mit dem Mobiltelefon gekoppelt und Signal läuft autark auf dem PC, nicht wie bei WhatsApp, Threema und co. Auch Videokonferenzen, Audiokonferenzen und die üblichen Signal-Features funktionieren hervorragend. Mit dem Befehl 'signal-desktop --start-in-tray --use-tray-icon' als Autostart läuft die App auch noch im Hintergrund und man verhindert die langen Ladezeiten. Sehr gut gelungen!
summary: Mit Abstand der beste Messenger-Client auf dem PC

description: me gusta mucho signal, gracias por hacer un flatpak para usarlo facilmente!
Je recommande cette application pour éviter l'espionnage généralisé de Google/Facebook sur nos communications. Dommage qu'il n'y ait pas plus d'utilisateurs !
Je recommande Signal qui contrairement à Telegram est totalement Open Source et n'est pas accusé de "Sécurité par l'obscurité" d'après de nombreux développeurs.
Il ne manque que la visio à plusieurs !
Sécurité au top, respect de la vie privée au top, confortable comme les autres applications de messagerie. Ça marche même pour voir sa famille en vidéo.

Signal chiffre vraiment tout, et que ce soit sur le téléphone ou l'application de bureau. Je ne recommande, pour l'heure, que cette application et rien d'autre.
Seul défaut, que les notifications ne s'arrêtent pas automatiquement après un certain temps/nombre de messages, quand un groupe discute et que vous faites autre chose. Vous devez vous même rendre muet le groupe (pendant un temps donné), mais je sais que l'application va proposer ça rapidement.

Signal est tout simplement la meilleure application de messagerie sécurisée. Open source, elle propose des fonctionnalités qui égalent pourtant ses concurrents ayant un code bien plus obscure. Un très bon outil pour qui la vie privée doit, comme son nom l'indique doit être privée.

How run app over proxy? Example proxychains.
$ proxychains flatpak run org.signal.Signal
Великолепное приложение! Классика мессенджеров!
